About

We are a computational neuroscience research group and part of the Bristol Computational Neuroscience Unit at the University of Bristol in the fine city of Bristol, UK.

Research

We work on three main areas: Learning & Memory, Autism, and Statistical methods for neural data.

Learning and Memory
- What are the mechanisms and rules of synaptic plasticity? Work by Beatriz, Rachel and Cian.
- Heterosynaptic plasticity: how do neighboring synapses on a dendrite influence each other? Work by Rahul and Sofia.
- How does neural replay during sleep contribute to memory? Work by Will and Kipp.
- How does mitochondria trafficking affect synapse turnover in axons? Work by Naomi.

Statistical methods for neural data
How should we analyse data from large numbers of neurons? We work on statistical methods for analysing large-scale neural datasets, including: probabilistic models of neural population activity distributions, network science methods, and bayesian hierarchal modelling.
Work by Sydney, Kipp and Cian.

Autism
What is different in the brains of autistic people? We collaborate with researchers who work on animal models of autism to ask what is different at the level of neural circuits. Currently we are working on the neural variability hypothesis: that the brains of autistic people respond with more variability to sensory stimuli. Also asking how computational modelling can inform neural circuit-level understanding of autism mechanisms.
Work by Beatriz and Cian.
